title: Roadside to Everyone (R2E) Phase 1: Physical & Local Vulnerabilities in (C)V2X RSUs
historical_context: This article is part of a multi-phased research project exploring vulnerabilities in roadside units (RSUs) used in Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication, highlighting the security risks associated with the increasing deployment of these devices.
target_audience: Security researchers, hackers, automotive security professionals, and those interested in V2X technology.
short_summary: The article investigates physical and local vulnerabilities in roadside units (RSUs) used for Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication. It details how these devices can be compromised with minimal physical access, leading to severe implications for public safety and infrastructure integrity. The author presents findings from Phase 1 of the research, which includes multiple CVEs related to the vulnerabilities discovered.
summary: In this article, Jon Gaines delves into the vulnerabilities of roadside units (RSUs) that facilitate Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication. The research highlights the alarming ease with which these devices can be physically compromised, allowing attackers to gain persistent control without sophisticated tools or techniques. The author emphasizes the critical role of RSUs in managing traffic and assisting autonomous vehicles, underscoring the potential dangers of a compromised unit, such as misleading vehicles or endangering pedestrians. The paper outlines the attack surface, including hardware vulnerabilities, insecure firmware, and improper access controls, leading to the discovery of seven CVEs that expose these weaknesses. Gaines provides detailed methodologies for achieving root access and discusses the implications of these vulnerabilities for public safety and infrastructure integrity, calling for urgent attention to securing these devices as they become more prevalent in smart transportation systems.
additional_notes: The article serves as a wake-up call for stakeholders in the automotive and transportation sectors, urging them to prioritize security measures for RSUs to prevent potential exploitation that could have catastrophic consequences.
